intro: Bupleurum latissimum, commonly known as broadleaf angelica, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its roots are often harvested for their medicinal properties, used in traditional medicine for their purported anti-inflammatory and antispasmodic effects. Bupleurum latissimum thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forested or rocky habitats.
